SC Aiming for December Governance Report
By DON LASSUS
Pressing their drive for a new
governance system for
Homewood,the Student Council
organized a committee to
develop a governance report at
their Monday night session.
The Governance Committee
has been directed to file a
Preliminary report by December
The Council twice defeated a
motion calling for a referendum
of undergraduates on their
support of the SC's governance
move and the tactics employed—
such as cutting ties with the
administration and ending funds
to the Eisenhower Symposium.

Similarly, the SC defeated a
portion of the motion that
would require Council members
to resign if the student body
disapproved of the Council's ,ac—
tion.
Former SCmember and ASAC
representative Chris Ohly was
appointed to head the
Governance Committee, which is
a modification of the Committee
for a Student Senate. The
chairman of that committee,
John Crofford, resigned last
week.
The committee was charged
with the responsibility for
outlining a governance report for.
Homewood with all matters of
the committee being

accountable to the Student
Council. The committee plans to
meet three times a week to make
the Dec. 1 deadline.
At the beginning of the
meeting a motion was proposed
by sophomore representative
Sheppard Hoffman reaffirming
the Council's governance stand.
An attempt was made to tack an
amendment onto the motion
calling for a student referendum
to approve the Council's tactics,
and that disapproval would
require the Council to resign as
not representative of
undergraduates.

Militants Heckle Matveyev

Matveyev.
Protesting the treatment of
Jews in the Soviet Union, the
Jewish students aimed their
shouts at the chief political
Writer for Izvestia, Matveyev,
during his speech on the cold
war.
Stressing the "atomic bomb
diplomacy" of the United States
and England following World
War II as the chief cause of the
cold war, Matveyev appeared
calm during the disruptions in
the packed Shriver Hall.

Disagree on Science
(first ofa series)
By RICHARD WARING
One evening, a sophomore
taking organic chemistry was
trying to do his homework. He
found the work difficult and
frustration began to slow him
down. Finally, he could stand no
more. "Somebody save me
before I crack," he asked his
roommates.
Giving up on his homework,
he went to call his parents,
perhaps for encouragement and
advice. He apparently did not
get what he needed, for as soon
as he finished with his parents,
he ran to his room ,slammed his
door and collapsed in tears of
anger and frustration, with
chemistry and science in general.

Although this student's
reaction to Hopkins' science
courses is far from usual, it does
show the key elements many
students and some faculty
members find in the scientific
curriculum here.
Students complain of the
difficulty of the material, the
arrogance and apathy of the
professors, the heavy emphasis

on grades, the large size of the
introductory courses and the
incompetent graduate students
who teach many of the courses
in sections.
In their turn, some faculty
members complain that some
students themselves are
apathetic, uncommitted and
unsuited to Hopkins. Some also
see that courses are too large.
In terms of solutions, neither
faculty nor students see easy
answers to the problems of
undergraduate science
education.
But many faculty members
feel that Hopkins already offers
a good education to the student
who wants it, and is willing to
work to get it. They all
acknowledge the strong pre-med,
pre-professional emphasis of
Hopkins' education.
One student said, "The
professors are concerned with
their own reputations— they're
elitists."
Another commented, "The
science courses are pretty bad.
Too large a group of professors
show an 'I don't care' attitude:

Hopkins Securtt ...............;;;;

Med School
By BILL WITTING
Responding to a mounting outcry
over the lack of security at the Johns
llopkins Medical Institutions, the
University administration is taking steps
to improve the quality of security
personnel and to establish some control
over the entire security organization.
Contacted following the appearance
• of a November 9 News-Lifter article
documenting some of the failings of the
security system, Ronald De Matteo
emphasized that the administration is
aware of the need for reform and is
working to satisfy that need.
De Matteo, who assumed his present
•: position at Hopkins as Assistant
Administrator in charge of security on
the East Baltimore campus only three
months ago, stated that he has already
taken action to change the structure of
the security system.
Included in this reform program, he
indicated, are talks with the Pinkerton
Guardean agency which in the past has
provided all of the security personnel
who police the area, and the
.:•:•:• establishment of improved supervisory

administration itself.
Pinkerton Reform
He stated that efforts are being made
"to develop a closer relationship with
Pinkerton."
"I don't think Pinkerton is going to
be unresponsive at this point," he said.
De Matteo mentioned both training of
security police and improved
supervision as possible areas of
negotiation with Pinkerton.
"We also want to create guidelines
about how things are to be done in
certain situations," he commented.
According to the original News-Letter
report, Pinkerton guards themselves
have denied ever having had training for
their job. It also suggested that, left to
themselves to decide how to perform
their duties, many guards neglect them
rather than place themselves in any kind
of danger.
Pinkerton Supervised
To combat this problem, De Matteo
stated that a reorganization of the
security system is being planned. "We've
got to beef up our supervision in these
areas," he declared.
(continued on page 12)

Homewood

By SUE WOOLHISER
Despite contentions that security at
Hopkins is minimal, the administrators
of the program assert that precautions
on the Homewood campus are generally
effective.
According to George Weinbach, head
of campus security, the evening force
consists of one security man in a patrol
car and a number of night watchmen
who patrol within the buildings.
"I think we have adequate security,"
said Weinbach. "We are involved
principally with safeguarding rather
than enforcement," he added. He
presented the few incidents of crime of
campus as evidence of the efficacy of
campus protection.
Weinbach refused to disclose the
exact number of security personnel
employed by the University; the staff
consists of University employees and
some Pinkerton guards.
Although the total security budget is
S150.000 according to some members
of the Hopkins community a potentially
dangerous situation exists.
"I hardly ever see the campus police
on campus at nii,nt," said one night

school student. "We need to have more
protection at night."
Victim
Dr. Phoebe Stanton, who was
recently the victim of a purse snatching
attempt at night, commented, "I'm
annoyed because I can't walk home. I'm
.:•:•:.
scared."
"It has to do with the state of the
city and the nation." Stanton
continued, "I don't see how the
University can solve the problem merely
by putting money into security."

real problem with crime as in any urban:::::::

life."

The Goucher and JHU Young

Information Service of the

Hall.

WORLD'S GREATEST
The World's Greatest Jazz
Band will appear at the Famous
Ballroom (1717 North Charles)
tonight from 5-9 p.m. Stan
Kenton and his Orchestra will be
there on November 21. For
more information, call the JAZZ
LINE at 945-2266.

annual Exhibition of student
work beginning November 21.
Hours for the show, at the
Mount Royal Station Gallery,
will be from 9-5, Monday
through Friday, and 1-5 on
weekends.

Symposium Speech

are you going to let my people
go?"
Small groups of students
unfurled banners and began
chanting "Let my people go."
Matveyev stepped from the
podium until the demonstrators
were peacably evicted.
Continuing his speech,
Matveyev indicated that it was
the first time in his six visits to
the country that he had been the
target of such a demonstration.
He expressed the hope that the
problem could be solved to
avoid grievences.
His address continued for
fifteen minutes before the
demonstrators, who had
returned to the auditorium
promising no further
disruptions, began chanting and
singing again. Matveyev
remained at the lecturn

throughout the interruption. He
continued his speech, without
mention of the disruption, after
the demonstration was over.
In his speech Matveyev
charged the US with primary
responsibility for starting the
cold war with its threat of
nuclear warfare following World
War II. He stressed that the cold
war could have been avoided and
called for closer US-USSR
cooperation in ending military
blocks in Europe.
No Hypocrisy
During the question and
answer period following the
speech, the Jewish students
drilled Matveyev on Soviet
treatment of Jews.
"Arab countries object to
immigration to Israel," said
Matveyev. "I would be a
hyperite to say that we do not
listen to the Arab governments."

NEWS-LETTER

Top Administrators Meet the Freshmen
By LINDA SHARP
Freshmen casually clustered
around the University's top
administrators last Thursday
night in the Garrett Room of the
library, taking advantage of the
Opportunity to question or
complain directly to these men.
President Milton S.
Eisenhower and Provost Steven
Muller faced questions about the
problems and plans of the
University, while Dean of Arts
and Sciences George Benton was
primarily confronted with the
issue of governance.
Dean of Academic Programs
Sigmund Suskind and Freshman
Advisor Larry Ewing were
present to answer questions on
academic matters. Director of
Student Services Larry Denton
and Col. Robert Serena
discussed dormitory life, and
Student Activities Director
James Sydnor was on hand for
queries on extra-curricular
activites.
Nearly 100 students
Progressed around the room,
Pausing to listen to or question

the administrators. Eisenhower,
sitting beneath a grand portrait
of himself, discussed financial
matters.
New Programs
"We are moving in the right
direction with the decreasing
budget deficit," he remarked. He
also talked about the problems
of getting grants, explaining that
it is often easier to get money
for an new program than for the
maintenance of an old one.
"I am hopeful that a law
school will be high priority when
the new building programs
budget is announced on January
1, 1973. He continued, "A law
school at Hopkins has been my
dream since I came here."
On the subject of governance,
Benton expressed unhappiness
with student inaction. "The Academic Council has heard
absolutely nothing about a
University Senate from
responsible student
representatives; no proponents
of a plan have come in and given
me the particulars."
Benton views the main

purpose of a student senate to
be the communication of
student opinions and needs to
the administration. "We haven't
had an effective student
organization since I've been
here. We need an organized
student body," he stated.
Muller saw a desperate need
for the undergraduate view to be
expressed. "We would like to
discuss proposals of governance,
but the last thing we can do is
thrust governance down the
throats of undergraduates."
Citing the Library Committee
as an example, Muller stressed,
"The tragedy is that the
committee is taking policy
recommendations, but only
faculty are there."
Praise
Benton and Muller both spent
time praising Eisenhower. "If
the newpresident has good sense,
he will involve Eisenhower as an
advisor," Benton asserted.
Muller claimed, "Eisenhower's
name is legend."
Sydnor discussed student
activity funding with the

Questionnaire

BRP Set to Query Students
By WARREN GULIN
In an attempt to gain student
Opinion for its final report, the
Blue Ribbon Panel on
Undergraduate Education plans
to distribute a comprehensive
questionnaire to all students this
Wednesday.
The questionnaire which
covers student housing, class
size, advising, letter grading,
course offerings and social life,
consists of 82 questions and a
section devoted to write-in
comments. Three
undergraduates working for the
BRP composed the
questionnaire which was revised
twice by the full panel.
Dean of Undergraduate
Studies Sigmund R. Suskind,
Chairman of the BRP, stated,
"We need a one-hundred percent
response to the questionnaire. It
is essential to the successful
completion of the final draft."
Commenting on the student
body's role in the formulation of
the Report, he noted, "Without
input we're helpless. we can
hardly suggest changes in
undergraduate education if we
don't know what's on their
minds."
Receptive
Citing the panel's
receptiveness to student
recommendations for increased
course offerings, Dean Suskind
calls on all students to submit
their completed questionnaires
to designated drop-boxes no
later than 4:00 p.m. November
22 to offer suggestions for
further change.
Suskind dismissed the panel's
critics who labelled the Interim
Report "insubstantial," stating.
that it was a "respectable job"
and the product of many long
hours of work.
While working on the BRP,
Suskind was impressed by the
demeanor of the undergraduate

Sigmund R. Suskind
committee members— "The
questionnaire was put together
very seriously with much hard

work on their part."
In addition to furnishing a
hopefully objective study for the
improvement of undergraduate
programs, the report will
acquaint a board of examiners
from the Mid-Atlantic States
Association with Hopkins when
they visit in the spring. The
examiners will be evaluating the
education offered
undergraduates in a University
oriented toward pre-professional
training, using Hopkins as a case
study.
If the questionnaires are
received in sufficient quantity,•
the panel will expand on the
advising system and student
housing, issues only hinted at in
A.
the interim report.

money on this (the
Youngbloods) concert," he
predicted. Sydnor, however, is
no longer coordinating the
concert, since it has been taken
over by the Student Council.
Suskind listened to gripes
about large classes from the
students, then explained the
administrations procedure in
selecting undergraduate
instructors: "Some teachers are
very good with small groups, but
no good at lectures. They don't
teach undergraduates."
Teaching
On the subject of student

criticism of teachers as an aid in
tenure decisions, Benton said,
"We would welcome a serious
student evaluation of a
professor's teaching ability."
The program was organized
by freshman class president
Andrew Savitz and
vice-president Paul Stein. "It's
good for kids to get to know
who's running their University,"
said Savitz.
No Loitering
Some administrators and
students lingered past 10:00,
enjoying the conversation and
refreshments provided by the
program.

By JACKIE DOWD
Although no formal courses
will be offered by the Classics
Department during the
mini-mester, a seminar whose
theme centers on satire is being
organized and run by graduate
students.
The seminar, which will be
directed in conjunction with
graduate students of other
related departments, will be run
in accordance with a similar
program last year. Tom
Sienkewicz, coordinator of the
seminar, stated that the purpose
of the program was to get

together an inter-departmental
course, which would be open to
anyone interested.
"The seminar will be run in
almost the same way as it was
last year," explained Dr. Marsh
McCall, Classics Chairman.
"There are two meetings a week
for three weeks, and the sessions
can go on for two to three
hours. Last intersession no credit
was given for the course, and it
is expected that this year will be
the same" said McCall.
Experiment
Jean D'Amato, who helped to
organize last year's seminar, id
that it was the first experiment
of its type open to the entire
University. Even people not in
the University attended. She
stated, "The humanities
departments were doing nothing
about getting themselves put
together; we needed a course
which combined different
departments." Graduate
students in Classics, Spanish,
French, Italian, English and
German departments all
participated.
D'Amato explained that there
was a low enrollment of
undergraduates last year, and she
cited the lack of credits as the
probable cause. She concluded,
"We had a good exchange of
ideas and a big turnout. The
seminar achieved its purpose,
and should be termed
successful."
McCall stated that the Classics
Department was not offering
any formal courses during the
intersession because they didn't
see any great demand for it. He
explained, "The need for classic
courses at Hopkins isn't beyond
what is offered during the year."

Seminars Planned

Prexy Panel Talks Start
By MICHAEL GRANET
The President Selection
Committee is now planning to
begin interviews with
approximately 20 candidates for
University President.
"Though no interviewing has
begun," said Judge Harrison
Winter, chairman of the
Committee and Trustee Board
vice-chairman, "we are now
considering the advisory report
of about twenty names."
The Board plans to do the
interviewing and has agreed not
to place any additional names on
the list without student-faculty
committee review and action.
"The question of additional
names remains," added Winter.
Since President Eisenhower
has expressed a desire to leave
by the first of the year, a
decision will be made "as
quickly as possible," said Winter.
Faculty member of the
committee Dr. George Owen,

Physics, commended the work
of the Committee as "impartial
and democratic and very
impressive." He noted that the
Committee has "completed the
initial work two months ahead
of time."
Mark Derr, one of two
undergraduate Committee
members, said, "The process of
interviewing will include
students as interviewers, though
the exact process has yet to be
established." Committee
members have praised highly the
work of the undergraduates.
The recent Student Council
action to withdraw
undergraduate members and
support from any
administration -connected
committees includes the
President Selection Committee.
According to this action, Derr
and Andrew Loftus, the other
undergraduate member of the
committee, should resign.

"But the SC doesn't know
what it is up .to," commented
Derr. "More good can be done
by attempting to influence the
selection rather than support the
ambiguous position of the SC. I
intend to stay on the
Committee," he added.
Selection procedures began
early this summer with a Search
Committee asking Hopkins
community members for name
suggestions. Two hundred names
were submitted and then
screened by the two groups
within the Committee.
These two groups are the
Board of Trustees and
representatives of faculty,
students, and various branches
of the University. The Board will
make the final selection choice.
The now limited list of about
twenty names has been kept
secret to avoid candidate
alienation through public
exposure.

By HOWARD SIMONS
The Johns Hopkins chapter of
Women's Liberation aired a list
of grievances, including the
absence of a gynecologist at the
Health Center and the low
number of female students and
faculty, at a meeting last week.
Foremost among the
complaints presented was the
lack of an on-campus room for a
women's, association. They are
currently trying to get a room in
the basement of Shriver, an
attempt that has met with
failure so far because the group
is not a formally constituted,
Student Council-approved body.
Once they receive recognition,
they will apply for a room in the
projected Levering Student
Union. Other grievances
included the lack of an official
meeting place, and the absence
of contraceptives at the Health
Center.
Only five faculty members are
female, only two higher than in
1879, they charged. Two of the
five have been dismissed for next
year, they said, a move that the
group plans to protest
Contraceptives

undergraduates and 277 women
graduates at Hopkins, figures
that the group considers to be

Governance
The Student Council moved forward on the governance
issue Monday night. As a result of actions taken by the
Council, the prospect of a meaningful undergraduate
governing body seems more plausible today than it has for
some time.
The SC has organized a committee expressly charged
with the creation of a concrete governance report. Beyond
that, they have appointed a chairman for that committee,
and directed that a preliminary report be in their hands by
December 1.
The SC failed to take steps which might have given
students a greater chance to participate in the dubious
tactical planning of the Council's governance reform
movement.
They voted down two proposals which would have given
undergraduates the opportunity to comment on the
sweeping actions the SC has taken on behalf of governance
reform. While under fire for failing to represent students,
the SC has recently elected a vice-president and the
chairman of the new governance committee by what
amounts to executive fiat.
Regardless of how or why the Council operates,
however, the issue of governance reform has to take
precedence at this point. If students can effect a potent,
representative form of governance for Homewood, the
problems which arise in Student Council operations can be
•put aside forever.
Unless the Council can enlist strong student support for
their actions, however, no governance plan, however
polished, has a chance for implementation.
A

ctivities fee

The administration decision to phase out student
activities funding and the low voter turnout which
defeated a proposed fee hike are both regrettable: they
will leave campus activities with only S40,000 in two
years. The result will be the ending of minimally-funded
student activities and a major curtailing of larger groups.
To avoid this, some student leaders seem interested in the
idea of putting student activities into the University
budget, a move which would be disastrous for the
independence of student groups on campus. Although
there would be the short-term benefit of University
funding, all activities would be subject to fiscal review by
the administration— an implied threat to student groups
critical of University actions.

"All Clear — You Can Come Out Now — I Said,
All Clear — Say,Can You Fellows Hear Me?"

(addressed "to all Jewish
students ":)
There are a variety of good
reasons for reading the New
Testament besides the fact that I
will be freely offering to you the
gift of an Old Testament
Prophecy Edition New
Testament today and tomorrow
near the Library entrance. This
pocket size edition of the
complete New Testament shows
the Jewishness of Jesus and the
New Testament by placing the
hundreds of references to the
then-existing Hebrew Bible, the
Old Testament, in bold face type
with footnotes showing their
source. Also, there is a preface
showing important passages out
of the Law, the Writings and the
Prophets, the Tenach, that
describe two different comings
of one Messiah. The early
Hebrew Christian writers of the
New Testament were Messianic
Jews who believed that Jesus
had come once as the
Atonement, "The Lamb of God
Who takes away the sins of the
world," and that Messiah Jesus
would come back soon as the
Judge and Prince of Peace to set
up his Kingdom visibly on earth
from Jerusalem. But in the time
between the Messiah's comings,
the early Jewish Christians
enjoyed the presence of the risen
Christ through His Holy Spirit.
And by having the King of the
Universe in their life as King,
they experienced the Kingdom
of God even now in this life in
an internal, eternal and spiritual
way.

• Even if the above Messianic
faith seems like "too much" for
you at the present time, you
owe it to yourself and your
Creator to consider the exciting
possibility of becoming a son of
God through accepting the
Eternal Son of God as your
Messiah, Savior and Lord. The
New Testament comprises the
oldest and most authentic
history we have concerning
Jesus. And a very important part
of Jewish history is this
eyewitness Jewish testimony to
the first-coming of the Messiah.
The King James translation of
the New Testament which I will
give you is a classic of English
literature. But its spiritual

significance surpasses its literary
excellence.
I hope your desire to be
informed in history, literate in
English, and — most importantly
— enlightened in spirit will lead
you to drop by the Library and
receive your copy of the New
Testament. It is free to you if
you are Jewish and willing to
read it.
I want to share the Word of
God with you because, though
Gentile, through reading the
Jewish history of the New
Testament Scriptures I became
rich in Christ.
Shalom in Yeshud
haMashiach.
Richard McMullin

The Presidency

Campaign
Jim Cantor
George McGovern would give his eye-teeth to
exchange places with Ed Muskie. But the Junior
Senator from Maine has found out that the rank
of frontrunner may be less desirable than his
prospective competitors can imagine.
The tragedy at Chappaquidick and subsequent
elimination of Ted Kennedy as the most likely
Democratic nominee in 1972 catapulted the
soft-spoken hero of 1968 into the vacum that
had been created. That was in July, 1969, and
for over two years since, Muskie has been
regarded by almost every analyst and indicator as
the man to beat next July.
The enormous amount of exposure he has
received since then could hardly have failed to
push Muskie to a decision to seek the Presidency.
We live in fast-paced society, one in which no
sooner has one Presidential election occurred
than it becomes a chief source of attention in
many quarters to predict the winner of the next
one, four years hence. This puts the pressure on
prospective candidates to begin both covert
planning and public statements earlier than in the
past. Such a trend is evidenced by the fact that a
full year away from the '72 election we have seen
two men formally enter the race (one dropping
out shortly after) and three others formally
decline to enter after testing the "political
waters."
All of this is perfectly suitable for someone
like McGovern who is so far behind in the polls
that he needs all the time he can get to make
himself a "household word." But Muskie has
nothing to gain from great exposure and much to
lose. The danger of over-exposure is one that
Joe Cantor is a junior political science major.

worries his staff, who fear that his campaign
might peak too soon and collapse well in advance
of the convention. Greater exposure would result
in great pressure to capture in imagination of the
public, and being the relatively bland individual
he is, he knows he can't match a Kennedy or a
Lindsay in personal magnetism. That Muskie
might be too lackluster and dull to people by the
time primaries and the convention roll around is
a source of concern to those who work in his
behalf.
The more premature attention given to
Muskie, the more pressure he will be under to
take decisive stands on issues. This creates a
potential problem for the cautious Senator who
has a wide diversity of support in his party. He
can, by taking firm stands on issues, alienate the
right or the left, according to the nature of the
particular position. He finds himself sandwiched
between the relatively conservative,
establishment forces of the party and the more
liberal, reformist wing. The former (including
Senators Henry Jackson and Hubert Humphrey,
Congressman Wilbur Mills, and Sam Mayor Yorty
of Los Angeles) are engaged in a tug-of-war for
control of the party with the latter group (which
includes Senators Kennedy and McGovern,
former Senator Eugene McCarthy,
Congresswoman Shirley Chisholm, and Mayor
John Lindsay). Muskie stands in the middle,
clinging tenaciously to the Moderate point of
view when possible. When he does take a stand, it
is generally to the left— but almost always with
moderation. He knows he can't stray too far lest
he engage the active, possibly fatal, antagonism
from the powerful establishment wing2-- the old
coalition of labor forces, Southerners, and party
regulars.

PAGE 7

protocols of Matveyev
By FOCAL
It's not easy being a Russian
Journalist, as V.A. Matveyev well
knows after clawing his way to
the top in the tough world of
Moscow newspaperdom.
Matveyev also learned Friday
that it's not easy being a speaker
on an American campus,
especially when you have to face
down shouted disruptions and
hostile questions from Jewish
students protesting his country's
oppression of Jews.
Over there in the Soviet
Union, public speaking is
relatively easy. But
unfortunately, there's not much
opportunity to practice, since all
Speeches have to be cleared and
they're usually reserved for big
events, such as Mayday addresses
or the farewell speech before the
firing squad. Naturally, Russians
are hesitant about delivering
Witty off-the-cuff remarks and
so are not nearly as facile as
their American counterparts.
All this leaves men like
Matveyev at a great
disadvantage, since they have

not mastered the fine political
art of evading questions.
Matveyev also failed to warm the
crowd up with gags. Tensions
would have been greatly reduced
if he had only told the sure-fire
crowd pleaser about the two
Jews and the Polack stuck on a
desert island together. So what is
a man like Matveyev to do when
faced with the critical
questioners and anti-Soviet
protesters.
Ruski
But most of the people who
came to hear Mateyev were not
so interested in hearing about
the Cold War or protesting
oppression as they were in
actually finding out what a
Russian looks like, after being
raised on a barrage of Junior
Scholastic primers on the Red
Menace and filmclips on "Life
Behind The Iron Curtain."
"Although the leaders of these
two great powers often
disagree," the authoritative film
narrator always told us, "the
Soviet people themselves like
Americans." Among other

things, we learned that Russian
women are very fat and wear
burlap bags, and will mortgage
their homes for the chance to
buy nylons, which, like all such
goods are taken for granted by
Americans, are very scarce in
Russia. Russians also drink a lot
of vodka and enjoy swimming in
very cold water. Their national
sport is shotputting.
Matveyev fit the description
provided by the dossier from the
State Department and CIA spy
squads— "...black hair, brown
eyes, wears glasses, dresses
conservatively..."— as well as
closely resembling the fuzzy
photo taken from a camera
hidden in a lapel. While he was
dressed in a baggy suit, he did
not once use the word
"Amerikanski," which
disappointed many in the crowd.
Matveyev was clearly puzzled
by some of Jewish students'
questions, especially the one
which asked: "Although you
seem angry at these disruptions,
if you were a Jew in Russia, do
you not know that you would

not be permitted to speak out at
all?" His Russian mind, after
quickly translating, tried to
penetrate the English rhetoric of
the question. He repeated slowly
to himself, "If I was a Jew in
Russia..." Perhaps he felt the
question was a slur. "Are you
trying to say that I'm Jewish?
Watch your tongue, young
man!" he may have wanted to
reply.
Jews
In addition, Matveyev relied
on the some-of-my-best-friends-are-Jewish routine, citing a
friend of his named Polansky
who found no anti-Semitism in
Russia. He said, too, that
America had some "extreme
examples" of anti-Semitism. He
deleted from his speech, but
made available to the
News-Letter, references to
Jewish "clannishness" and
"curly-haired people with big
noses who think they're so
smart."
Most surprising was the fact
that he was there at all,
considering that he had been

newspaper reporter since the late
1940's in a country where a
misquoted official just doesn't
write an angry letter to the
editor. The machinations at the
New York Times are nothing
compared to the re-shufflings at
the Kremlin— and Izvestia. If
you can survive 38 purges, you
are truly a two-fisted,
thick-skinned, hard-nosed
journalist. The other problem
facing a Russian jo6rnalist is the
boredom comparable to a
university P.R. man, since
there's nothing to do but
re-write government statements.
There are no "hot stories," and,
besides, there's no one to scoop.
KOSYGIN NABBED IN LOVE
NEST; CP BIGWIG TAKES
BRIBE; and INSIDE A
SIBERIAN PRISON CAMP are
among the great stories you
never get to do. Matveyev, it
should be noted, spends most of
his time writing about and
visiting the United States, where
he can at last take out a
reporter's natural urge to do a
hatchet job on somebody.

J.R. Oppenheimer-science vs humanity at the Barn
By RICHARD ROSENTHAL
History was reenacted as
drama in the Theatre Hopkins
production ofIn the Matter ofJ.
Robert Oppenheimer, which
opened this weekend at the
Barn. Heinar Kipphardt's play,
translated from the German,
factually recreates the Atomic
Energy Commission's 1954
hearing to review the security
clearance of the noted nuclear
physicist.
The players in this excellent
Production portray with vivid
realism the tensions,
personalities and issues that
comprised the case. Dr.
Oppenheimer was suspected of
disloyalty to protect his friend
Chevalier, a professor of French
literature and confirmed
Communist, when the latter had
informed him of the possibility
of scientific espionage by the
Russians in 1942.

Second, Oppenheimer was
accused of impeding the progress
of the hydrogen bomb by
refusing to be enthusiastic about
the project.
W.P. Ellis, Humanities
professor at Essex Community
College, portrays the enigmatic
scientist with great insight and
sensitivity. The man whom
journalists named "father of the
atomic bomb," expresses his
painful moral scruples about
nuclear energy as applied to
warfare.
As an expert in service to the
government he was required to
determine how a bomb could be
dropped with maximum effect,
but this duty led him to the
inevitable schizophrenia of
today's scientist.
In one of the most moving
parts of the play, Oppenheimer
recollects his thoughts as he
witnessed the explosion of the

first hydrogen bomb at
Eniwetok Atoll in 1952. Two
passages from the Bhagavad
Cita stood out in his mind: "The
radiance of one thousand suns
which suddenly illuminate the
heavens, all in one moment—
thus the splendor of the
Lord."..."And I am Death, who
taketh all, who shatters worlds."
This he thought as the island of
Elugelab was obliterated.
Treason
Mr. Robb, counsel for the

A.E.C., is played by Robert
Walsh in one of the outstanding
performances of the evening.
Rob argues that Oppenheimer's
crime is "ideological treason."
His principal witness is Dr.
Edward Teller, the brilliant and
temperamental father of the
H-bomb. Teller 'testifies that he
first contemplated a
thermonuclear explosion with
Oppenheimer in 1942, but
criticizes Oppenheimer's
objection in 1945 to H-bomb

research, stating, "I wanted the
hydrogen bomb while other
people were playing around with
disarmament illusions." Robb
concludes that the tragedy of J.
Robert Oppenheimer was his
clinging to the utopian desire of
a classless society in a world
where nuclear weapons are
developed only to show that
they must never be used.
"ln the Matter of J. Robert
Oppenheimer" is an excellent
and relevant play, and the
Theatre Hopkins production
benefits greatly from very
capable actors. The set design
imbues a certain realism to the
proceedings, and the lighting and
narration are well-suited to the
play.
Theatre Hopkins, now in its
fifty-first season, will stage the
play six more times, November
19-21,26-28.

NEWS-LETTER

Nov. 16, 1971

Jethro Tull
By MICHAEL HILL
"I was just driving down Baltimore
Street and I saw the big crowd around the
Civic Center, and Ifigured the Milwaukee
Bucks were in town. So I went in and
asked for a $5.50 seat. But when I got
inside it was all dark, and the basketball
court was nowhere around. And I looked
up on stage and wooee, it looked like
Dancing Harry had gotten together with a
bunch of his friends. This wierd lookin'
fellow was doing things that the Pearl
couldn't have done."
Ian Anderson's stage presence comes
over as something of a cross between Rudolph Nureyev and Joe Cocker. Swirling
hands and pointed, booted feet; flashing
eyes that must have been visible to the
back row of the Upper Concourse; an arched back and wild, flying hair, somehow
keeping time as the flute would swirl up
into another riff.
Jethro Tull was here Sunday night and
it was a battle of the egos the likes of
which hadn't been seen since Cream graced the Civic Center. Of course Ian Anderson, the best one-on-one singer in the
business, won, as per the game plan; but
it was quite a struggle and over 13,000
people really enjoyed watching.
The only problem was that the show
took place in the Civic Center. The Philadelphia 76ers had battled the Bullets
there the night before and the cavernous
hall was much more up for housing their
talents than it was for containing the
sounds of Tull.
Echoes abounded. Beats were impossible to distinguish as a rap from the snare
drum would come back at you a half second later. Anderson's incredible voice
would start out sounding like its amazing
self, and then quickly become muddled
and lost in the rebounding sounds.

Somehow it's not only the acoustics of
the Civic Center that are bothersome. The
massive entrances and exits, with their
square cinder block sides, seem more reasonable when filled with beer-swilling
hockey fans. Gaudily clad freaks somehow seem absurd disappearing into the
mass-production toilets. Hanging directly
above the stage during the evening were
the pennants won by the Bullets and Clippers, not to mention the neon U. S. flag,
which luckily never made an appearance.

But despite all that, Jethro Tull could
somehow make you forget. The bass player strutted back and forth in his zebra
suit and introduced one song with something about spending 18 months in an
asylum for exposing himself. All five preceded another song by standing in a line
and grunting out "New Day Yesterday."
Included in that line was the drummer
who wore a red hotpants outfit, complete
with knee socks and combat boots. Then
there was the keyboard man who stalked
acioss stage between the piano and organ,
his baggy white suit flowing with him,
looking something like Peter Ustinov after about six hits of sunshine.

The battle of the weirdness was part of
And the music, obviously some of the
the battle of the egos. Everyone knew the best produced, was at its most incredible.
part the others were to play, there were The complex patterns giving rise to mufew improvisational surprises. The fight sical flights of flute or piano. A new song
came in trying to play your part better (part of their forthcoming album "Thick
than anyone else played his. While the as a Brick") showed that stagnation has
guitarist was playing a break, Anderson
not accompanied their success. In the
would stalk around stage, fingering his end, a half-hour encore had everyone on
flute which was sticking out of his black- their feet with music of such intensity
tighted crotch, and the organist would
that it made you forget the name of the
reach around the neck of the guitar and song they were playing. You had no idea
pretend to be playing.
where it had begun or where it would
end. But finally, it did end,just as it had
begun, with Ian Anderson alone in the
spotlight, playing the flattop, his tassled
boots and flowing coat at last at rest. He
had started it by singing the first lines of
"My God" followed by an incredible
flute solo that brought the house down.
He closed it, following the noise and intensity, quietly, singing the last lines to
"Wind Up,"("A song written to say `Tata'"), then striding suddenly offstage, and
again the applause was thunderous.
Ian Anderson had won, as everyone
had known he would. But somehow the
battle was still real and we had all enjoyed watching.

The fames Gang, a
rock trio, will be
featured at the
Civic Center on
Nov. 21, along
with Lighthouse,
and Mitch Ryder &
the Detroit Wheels.

Well into this season's

with the Baltimore Racquet

Club, 4-1, and the Towson "Y,"
4-1, indicating the traditional
superiority of Homewood's
squash players. The Homewood

State League team champion

;lash this season.

and two players respectively.

New England prep schools:

Hampshire, and Hament at
Phillip's Academy, Andover
Massachusetts.
Resigning

from the team and turning over
his captain's duties to Steven
Anderson, who moves up the
ladder now to the number three
position.

Southern California, has also
played for the team since its
conception.

Russel-Wood, a professor in the
History Department, who has
played only England until this
year, and David Garrison, a

graduate student in the
Department of Romance
Languages. Bob Hogan, a
professor in the Psychology

competing for the now vacant
fifth position.

Hopkins Swordsmen
Seeking League Title
By INGRAM ROBERTS
This winter the Hopkins
fencers renew their pursuit of
the Middle Atlantic Conference
championship, which for the
past two years they have
narrowly missed capturing from
defending champion Temple.
The team will also enter the
North Atlantic Championships
and the NCAA championships
this year.
The Blue Jays will be
bolstered by five returning
lettermen: Co-Captains Keith
Bucklen and Ingram Roberts,
Jeff Rosenbaum, Tas Coroneos,
and Gary Green. Last year
Rosenbaum, Bucklen, and
Roberts were named to All-MAC
team. For the first time in recent
years, five out of nine starters
will be lettermen. The squad
should be strong and have a

good chance at improving on last
year's 6-5 record.
Besides the usual matches
against MAC opponents
Haverford, Drew, Stevens,
Lafayette, Muhlenberg, and
Temple, the team will be taking
a trip to New England and New
York City during mini-mester.
The fencers will take on 8 teams
including Harvard and MIT
during the course of this tour.
Other Opponents
Other matches against
perennial foes Duke, Virginia,
and Penn State are also on tap.
The team members are
optimistically viewing this year's
season, and feel it will be
perhaps both the most exciting
and successful one since 1967,
when Hopkins won the North
Atlantic Conference
Championship.

Woman Claims Abortion Clinic 'Nightmare'
By HOWARD WEAVER
The Wickersham Women's
Medical Clinic, an abortion clinic
which advertises in the
' News-Letter, has come under
attack from a Canadian woman
who was referred to the center
by her doctor.
The Toronto Globe and Mail,
in a November 5 story, told of
the woman's stay at the clinic,
which she described as a
"nightmare experience." She
went to the clinic in September,

after she failed in her attempt to
have the abortion in Toronto.
The Wickersham Clinic is in New
York.
The young woman — in her
early twenties — is the mother of
two children. She sought the
abortion because she is separated
from her husband and felt that
she could not afford another
child. An office worker, she
earns about $115 per week; she
borrowed the $400 needed for
the abortion, and spent another

$200 for travel costs.
The woman reported
inefficiency and neglect at the
clinic, which charged her $400
to abort the 18-week pregnancy.
The clinic, which in its
advertising bills the service as a
"Model Abortion Program," was
crowded and poorly staffed, she
said. Members of the clinic staff
treated her in a "contemptuous
and humiliating manner" during
her stay, according to the
woman.

Abortion Ads Challenged
By GARY SOULSMAN
The Diamondback, the
University of Maryland's student
newspaper, has come under
attack by the Knights of
Columbus for running abortion
referral ads.
The News-Letter runs similar
ads and is among numerous
organizations which the Knights
claim are violating Maryland's
1968 abortion law.
The Diamondback has
rejected a request from the
Knights to drop their
advertisements and it has
challenged the Knights to file
suit. The Catholic Men's
organization is presently
awaiting the opinion of
Maryland's Attorney General,
Francis Burch, to determine
whether or not they have a valid
case.
Joseph Mauro who is leading
the campaign for the Knights
said in an interview with the

Sunpapers, "We are dealing with
human life and this far
outweighs a newspaper's right to
publish these advertisements."
The controversy over
abortions stems from
an
by
interpretation
anti-abortionist groups such as
the Knights, over Maryland's
abortion law, which states that
abortions may be performed by
licensed physicians in
state-licensed hospitals.
One particular aspect of the
bill forbids "giving advice or
counsel information" or
assistance "by any means
whatever...for termination of
human pregnancy by such
physician in such hospital."
The Knights have interpreted
this to mean that any agency is
violating the law if it participates
in the practice of referring
Maryland women to Washington
where the red tape is less and the
abortions are cheaper.

Baltimore's branch of Planned
Parenthood which has been
referring people to Washington
has decided to ignore the
controversy. According to Carl
Speckman, the branch's director,
his organization has no choice
but to continue its referrals as
long as inadequate facilities are
called on to handle a greater
number of women seeking
abortions than they can handle.
Ironically, the Maryland State
Department of Health and
Mental Hygiene maternity and
family planning section has been
investigating the possibility of
establishing a permanent
relationship with a Washington
clinic to handle Maryland cases.
The agency thinks this would be
preferred by most women since
on the average abortions are
$150 cheaper there. However,
this organization will not send
anyone to Washington until the
present controversy is resolved.

The woman's alleged ordeal
began at 1:00 p.m., when she
and a number of other women
were told to report to the clinic.
After completing a form of
personal questions, she signed a
statement authorizing the
procedure, and the use of any
anesthetic required. The forms
listed her doctor as I. Saxe, but
she says that he was not
available for the actual abortion;
she does not know the name of
the young doctor who actually
carried out the saline-injection
procedure.
After a brief examination, she
was taken to a four-bed room
and the injection and a local

anesthetic were administered.
About 9:00 p.m., she began
labor, and started delivery at
4:00 a.m., but the nurse refused
to change the bed-linen until the
delivery was complete. No one
came to advise or help her
during the delivery, she said. She
was finally taken from the wet
bed at 10:00 a.m. Sunday, six
hours later. She was awakened at
6:00 a.m. Monday morning, and
kept waiting for examination
until 9:00 a.m.
"There's no privacy," she
said. "Half the time they don't
even close the door and there are
male staff walking about. The
cleaners walk in and out."

Med School
By BILL WITTING
Responding to a mounting outcry
over the lack of security at the Johns
llopkins Medical Institutions, the
University administration is taking steps
to improve the quality of security
personnel and to establish some control
over the entire security organization.
Contacted following the appearance
• of a November 9 News-Lifter article
documenting some of the failings of the
security system, Ronald De Matteo
emphasized that the administration is
aware of the need for reform and is
working to satisfy that need.
De Matteo, who assumed his present
•: position at Hopkins as Assistant
Administrator in charge of security on
the East Baltimore campus only three
months ago, stated that he has already
taken action to change the structure of
the security system.
Included in this reform program, he
indicated, are talks with the Pinkerton
Guardean agency which in the past has
provided all of the security personnel
who police the area, and the
.:•:•:• establishment of improved supervisory

administration itself.
Pinkerton Reform
He stated that efforts are being made
"to develop a closer relationship with
Pinkerton."
"I don't think Pinkerton is going to
be unresponsive at this point," he said.
De Matteo mentioned both training of
security police and improved
supervision as possible areas of
negotiation with Pinkerton.
"We also want to create guidelines
about how things are to be done in
certain situations," he commented.
According to the original News-Letter
report, Pinkerton guards themselves
have denied ever having had training for
their job. It also suggested that, left to
themselves to decide how to perform
their duties, many guards neglect them
rather than place themselves in any kind
of danger.
Pinkerton Supervised
To combat this problem, De Matteo
stated that a reorganization of the

Despite contentions that security at

campus as evidence of the efficacy of
campus protection.
Weinbach refused to disclose the
exact number of security personnel
employed by the University; the staff
consists of University employees and
some Pinkerton guards.

S150.000 according to some members

Top Administrators Meet the Freshmen
By LINDA SHARP
Freshmen casually clustered
around the University's top
administrators last Thursday
night in the Garrett Room of the
library, taking advantage of the
Opportunity to question or
complain directly to these men.
President Milton S.
Eisenhower and Provost Steven
Muller faced questions about the
problems and plans of the
University, while Dean of Arts
and Sciences George Benton was
primarily confronted with the
issue of governance.
Dean of Academic Programs
Sigmund Suskind and Freshman
Advisor Larry Ewing were
present to answer questions on
academic matters. Director of
Student Services Larry Denton
and Col. Robert Serena
discussed dormitory life, and
Student Activities Director
James Sydnor was on hand for
queries on extra-curricular
activites.
Nearly 100 students
Progressed around the room,
Pausing to listen to or question

the administrators. Eisenhower,
sitting beneath a grand portrait
of himself, discussed financial
matters.
New Programs
"We are moving in the right
direction with the decreasing
budget deficit," he remarked. He
also talked about the problems
of getting grants, explaining that
it is often easier to get money
for an new program than for the
maintenance of an old one.
"I am hopeful that a law
school will be high priority when
the new building programs
budget is announced on January
1, 1973. He continued, "A law
school at Hopkins has been my
dream since I came here."
On the subject of governance,
Benton expressed unhappiness
with student inaction. "The Academic Council has heard
absolutely nothing about a
University Senate from
responsible student
representatives; no proponents
of a plan have come in and given
me the particulars."
Benton views the main

purpose of a student senate to
be the communication of
student opinions and needs to
the administration. "We haven't
had an effective student
organization since I've been
here. We need an organized
student body," he stated.
Muller saw a desperate need
for the undergraduate view to be
expressed. "We would like to
discuss proposals of governance,
but the last thing we can do is
thrust governance down the
throats of undergraduates."
Citing the Library Committee
as an example, Muller stressed,
"The tragedy is that the
committee is taking policy
recommendations, but only
faculty are there."
Praise
Benton and Muller both spent
time praising Eisenhower. "If
the newpresident has good sense,
he will involve Eisenhower as an
advisor," Benton asserted.
Muller claimed, "Eisenhower's
name is legend."
Sydnor discussed student
activity funding with the

BRP Set to Query Students
By WARREN GULIN
In an attempt to gain student
Opinion for its final report, the
Blue Ribbon Panel on
Undergraduate Education plans
to distribute a comprehensive
questionnaire to all students this
Wednesday.
The questionnaire which
covers student housing, class
size, advising, letter grading,
course offerings and social life,
consists of 82 questions and a
section devoted to write-in
comments. Three
undergraduates working for the
BRP composed the
questionnaire which was revised
twice by the full panel.
Dean of Undergraduate
Studies Sigmund R. Suskind,
Chairman of the BRP, stated,
"We need a one-hundred percent
response to the questionnaire. It
is essential to the successful
completion of the final draft."
Commenting on the student
body's role in the formulation of
the Report, he noted, "Without
input we're helpless. we can
hardly suggest changes in
undergraduate education if we
don't know what's on their
minds."
Receptive
Citing the panel's
receptiveness to student
recommendations for increased
course offerings, Dean Suskind
calls on all students to submit
their completed questionnaires
to designated drop-boxes no
later than 4:00 p.m. November
22 to offer suggestions for
further change.
Suskind dismissed the panel's
critics who labelled the Interim
Report "insubstantial," stating.
that it was a "respectable job"
and the product of many long
hours of work.
While working on the BRP,
Suskind was impressed by the
demeanor of the undergraduate

Sigmund R. Suskind
committee members— "The
questionnaire was put together
very seriously with much hard

work on their part."
In addition to furnishing a
hopefully objective study for the
improvement of undergraduate
programs, the report will
acquaint a board of examiners
from the Mid-Atlantic States
Association with Hopkins when
they visit in the spring. The
examiners will be evaluating the
education offered
undergraduates in a University
oriented toward pre-professional
training, using Hopkins as a case
study.
If the questionnaires are
received in sufficient quantity,•
the panel will expand on the
advising system and student
housing, issues only hinted at in
A.
the interim report.

money on this (the
Youngbloods) concert," he
predicted. Sydnor, however, is
no longer coordinating the
concert, since it has been taken

Suskind listened to gripes
about large classes from the
students, then explained the
administrations procedure in
selecting undergraduate
instructors: "Some teachers are
very good with small groups, but
no good at lectures. They don't
teach undergraduates."
Teaching
On the subject of student

criticism of teachers as an aid in
tenure decisions, Benton said,
"We would welcome a serious
student evaluation of a
professor's teaching ability."
The program was organized
by freshman class president
Andrew Savitz and
vice-president Paul Stein. "It's
good for kids to get to know
who's running their University,"
said Savitz.
No Loitering
Some administrators and
students lingered past 10:00,
enjoying the conversation and
refreshments provided by the
program.

By JACKIE DOWD
Although no formal courses
will be offered by the Classics
Department during the
mini-mester, a seminar whose
theme centers on satire is being
organized and run by graduate
students.
The seminar, which will be
directed in conjunction with
graduate students of other
related departments, will be run
in accordance with a similar
program last year. Tom
Sienkewicz, coordinator of the
seminar, stated that the purpose
of the program was to get

together an inter-departmental
course, which would be open to
anyone interested.
"The seminar will be run in
almost the same way as it was
last year," explained Dr. Marsh
McCall, Classics Chairman.
"There are two meetings a week
for three weeks, and the sessions
can go on for two to three
hours. Last intersession no credit
was given for the course, and it
is expected that this year will be
the same" said McCall.
Experiment
Jean D'Amato, who helped to
organize last year's seminar, id
that it was the first experiment
of its type open to the entire
University. Even people not in
the University attended. She
stated, "The humanities
departments were doing nothing
about getting themselves put
together; we needed a course
which combined different
departments." Graduate
students in Classics, Spanish,
French, Italian, English and
German departments all
participated.
D'Amato explained that there
was a low enrollment of
undergraduates last year, and she
cited the lack of credits as the
probable cause. She concluded,
"We had a good exchange of
ideas and a big turnout. The
seminar achieved its purpose,
and should be termed
successful."
McCall stated that the Classics
Department was not offering
any formal courses during the
intersession because they didn't
see any great demand for it. He
explained, "The need for classic
courses at Hopkins isn't beyond
what is offered during the year."

Seminars Planned

Prexy Panel Talks Start
By MICHAEL GRANET
The President Selection
Committee is now planning to
begin interviews with
approximately 20 candidates for
University President.
"Though no interviewing has
begun," said Judge Harrison
Winter, chairman of the
Committee and Trustee Board
vice-chairman, "we are now
considering the advisory report
of about twenty names."
The Board plans to do the
interviewing and has agreed not
to place any additional names on
the list without student-faculty
committee review and action.
"The question of additional
names remains," added Winter.
Since President Eisenhower
has expressed a desire to leave
by the first of the year, a
decision will be made "as
quickly as possible," said Winter.
Faculty member of the
committee Dr. George Owen,

Physics, commended the work
of the Committee as "impartial
and democratic and very
impressive." He noted that the
Committee has "completed the
initial work two months ahead
of time."
Mark Derr, one of two
undergraduate Committee
members, said, "The process of
interviewing will include
students as interviewers, though
the exact process has yet to be
established." Committee
members have praised highly the
work of the undergraduates.
The recent Student Council
action to withdraw
undergraduate members and
support from any
administration -connected
committees includes the
President Selection Committee.
According to this action, Derr
and Andrew Loftus, the other
undergraduate member of the
committee, should resign.

"But the SC doesn't know
what it is up .to," commented
Derr. "More good can be done
by attempting to influence the
selection rather than support the
ambiguous position of the SC. I
intend to stay on the
Committee," he added.
Selection procedures began
early this summer with a Search
Committee asking Hopkins
community members for name
suggestions. Two hundred names
were submitted and then
screened by the two groups
within the Committee.
These two groups are the
Board of Trustees and
representatives of faculty,
students, and various branches
of the University. The Board will
make the final selection choice.
The now limited list of about
twenty names has been kept
secret to avoid candidate
alienation through public
exposure.

Governance
The Student Council moved forward on the governance
issue Monday night. As a result of actions taken by the
Council, the prospect of a meaningful undergraduate
governing body seems more plausible today than it has for
some time.
The SC has organized a committee expressly charged
with the creation of a concrete governance report. Beyond
that, they have appointed a chairman for that committee,
and directed that a preliminary report be in their hands by
December 1.
The SC failed to take steps which might have given
students a greater chance to participate in the dubious
tactical planning of the Council's governance reform
movement.
They voted down two proposals which would have given
undergraduates the opportunity to comment on the
sweeping actions the SC has taken on behalf of governance
reform. While under fire for failing to represent students,
the SC has recently elected a vice-president and the
chairman of the new governance committee by what
amounts to executive fiat.
Regardless of how or why the Council operates,
however, the issue of governance reform has to take
precedence at this point. If students can effect a potent,
representative form of governance for Homewood, the
problems which arise in Student Council operations can be
•put aside forever.
Unless the Council can enlist strong student support for
their actions, however, no governance plan, however
polished, has a chance for implementation.
A

ctivities fee

The administration decision to phase out student
activities funding and the low voter turnout which
defeated a proposed fee hike are both regrettable: they
will leave campus activities with only S40,000 in two
years. The result will be the ending of minimally-funded
student activities and a major curtailing of larger groups.
To avoid this, some student leaders seem interested in the
idea of putting student activities into the University
budget, a move which would be disastrous for the
independence of student groups on campus. Although
there would be the short-term benefit of University
funding, all activities would be subject to fiscal review by
the administration— an implied threat to student groups
critical of University actions.

"All Clear — You Can Come Out Now — I Said,
All Clear — Say,Can You Fellows Hear Me?"

(addressed "to all Jewish
students ":)
There are a variety of good
reasons for reading the New
Testament besides the fact that I
will be freely offering to you the
gift of an Old Testament
Prophecy Edition New
Testament today and tomorrow
near the Library entrance. This
pocket size edition of the
complete New Testament shows
the Jewishness of Jesus and the
New Testament by placing the
hundreds of references to the
then-existing Hebrew Bible, the
Old Testament, in bold face type
with footnotes showing their
source. Also, there is a preface
showing important passages out
of the Law, the Writings and the
Prophets, the Tenach, that
describe two different comings
of one Messiah. The early
Hebrew Christian writers of the
New Testament were Messianic
Jews who believed that Jesus
had come once as the
Atonement, "The Lamb of God
Who takes away the sins of the
world," and that Messiah Jesus
would come back soon as the
Judge and Prince of Peace to set
up his Kingdom visibly on earth
from Jerusalem. But in the time
between the Messiah's comings,
the early Jewish Christians
enjoyed the presence of the risen
Christ through His Holy Spirit.
And by having the King of the
Universe in their life as King,
they experienced the Kingdom
of God even now in this life in
an internal, eternal and spiritual
way.

• Even if the above Messianic
faith seems like "too much" for
you at the present time, you
owe it to yourself and your
Creator to consider the exciting
possibility of becoming a son of
God through accepting the
Eternal Son of God as your
Messiah, Savior and Lord. The
New Testament comprises the
oldest and most authentic
history we have concerning
Jesus. And a very important part
of Jewish history is this
eyewitness Jewish testimony to
the first-coming of the Messiah.
The King James translation of
the New Testament which I will
give you is a classic of English
literature. But its spiritual

significance surpasses its literary
excellence.
I hope your desire to be
informed in history, literate in
English, and — most importantly

you to drop by the Library and

Testament. It is free to you if

read it.
I want to share the Word of
God with you because, though
Gentile, through reading the
Jewish history of the New
Testament Scriptures I became
rich in Christ.
Shalom in Yeshud
haMashiach.
Richard McMullin

The Presidency

Campaign
Jim Cantor
George McGovern would give his eye-teeth to
exchange places with Ed Muskie. But the Junior
Senator from Maine has found out that the rank
of frontrunner may be less desirable than his
prospective competitors can imagine.
The tragedy at Chappaquidick and subsequent
elimination of Ted Kennedy as the most likely
Democratic nominee in 1972 catapulted the
soft-spoken hero of 1968 into the vacum that
had been created. That was in July, 1969, and
for over two years since, Muskie has been
regarded by almost every analyst and indicator as
the man to beat next July.
The enormous amount of exposure he has
received since then could hardly have failed to
push Muskie to a decision to seek the Presidency.
We live in fast-paced society, one in which no
sooner has one Presidential election occurred
than it becomes a chief source of attention in
many quarters to predict the winner of the next
one, four years hence. This puts the pressure on
prospective candidates to begin both covert
planning and public statements earlier than in the
past. Such a trend is evidenced by the fact that a
full year away from the '72 election we have seen
two men formally enter the race (one dropping
out shortly after) and three others formally
decline to enter after testing the "political
waters."
All of this is perfectly suitable for someone
like McGovern who is so far behind in the polls
that he needs all the time he can get to make
himself a "household word." But Muskie has
nothing to gain from great exposure and much to
lose. The danger of over-exposure is one that
Joe Cantor is a junior political science major.

worries his staff, who fear that his campaign
might peak too soon and collapse well in advance
of the convention. Greater exposure would result
in great pressure to capture in imagination of the
public, and being the relatively bland individual
he is, he knows he can't match a Kennedy or a
Lindsay in personal magnetism. That Muskie
might be too lackluster and dull to people by the
time primaries and the convention roll around is
a source of concern to those who work in his
behalf.
The more premature attention given to
Muskie, the more pressure he will be under to
take decisive stands on issues. This creates a
potential problem for the cautious Senator who
has a wide diversity of support in his party. He
can, by taking firm stands on issues, alienate the
right or the left, according to the nature of the
particular position. He finds himself sandwiched
between the relatively conservative,
establishment forces of the party and the more
liberal, reformist wing. The former (including
Senators Henry Jackson and Hubert Humphrey,
Congressman Wilbur Mills, and Sam Mayor Yorty
of Los Angeles) are engaged in a tug-of-war for
control of the party with the latter group (which
includes Senators Kennedy and McGovern,
former Senator Eugene McCarthy,
Congresswoman Shirley Chisholm, and Mayor
John Lindsay). Muskie stands in the middle,
clinging tenaciously to the Moderate point of
view when possible. When he does take a stand, it
is generally to the left— but almost always with
moderation. He knows he can't stray too far lest
he engage the active, possibly fatal, antagonism
from the powerful establishment wing2-- the old
coalition of labor forces, Southerners, and party
regulars.

protocols of Matveyev
By FOCAL
It's not easy being a Russian
Journalist, as V.A. Matveyev well
knows after clawing his way to
the top in the tough world of
Moscow newspaperdom.
Matveyev also learned Friday
that it's not easy being a speaker
on an American campus,
especially when you have to face
down shouted disruptions and
hostile questions from Jewish
students protesting his country's
oppression of Jews.
Over there in the Soviet
Union, public speaking is
relatively easy. But
unfortunately, there's not much
opportunity to practice, since all
Speeches have to be cleared and
they're usually reserved for big
events, such as Mayday addresses
or the farewell speech before the
firing squad. Naturally, Russians
are hesitant about delivering
Witty off-the-cuff remarks and
so are not nearly as facile as
their American counterparts.
All this leaves men like
Matveyev at a great
disadvantage, since they have

not mastered the fine political
art of evading questions.
Matveyev also failed to warm the
crowd up with gags. Tensions
would have been greatly reduced
if he had only told the sure-fire
crowd pleaser about the two
Jews and the Polack stuck on a
desert island together. So what is
a man like Matveyev to do when
faced with the critical
questioners and anti-Soviet
protesters.
Ruski
But most of the people who
came to hear Mateyev were not
so interested in hearing about
the Cold War or protesting
oppression as they were in
actually finding out what a
Russian looks like, after being
raised on a barrage of Junior
Scholastic primers on the Red
Menace and filmclips on "Life
Behind The Iron Curtain."
"Although the leaders of these
two great powers often
disagree," the authoritative film
narrator always told us, "the
Soviet people themselves like
Americans." Among other

things, we learned that Russian
women are very fat and wear
burlap bags, and will mortgage
their homes for the chance to
buy nylons, which, like all such
goods are taken for granted by
Americans, are very scarce in
Russia. Russians also drink a lot
of vodka and enjoy swimming in
very cold water. Their national
sport is shotputting.
Matveyev fit the description
provided by the dossier from the
State Department and CIA spy
squads— "...black hair, brown
eyes, wears glasses, dresses
conservatively..."— as well as
closely resembling the fuzzy
photo taken from a camera
hidden in a lapel. While he was
dressed in a baggy suit, he did
not once use the word
"Amerikanski," which
disappointed many in the crowd.
Matveyev was clearly puzzled
by some of Jewish students'
questions, especially the one
which asked: "Although you
seem angry at these disruptions,
if you were a Jew in Russia, do
you not know that you would

not be permitted to speak out at
all?" His Russian mind, after
quickly translating, tried to
penetrate the English rhetoric of
the question. He repeated slowly
to himself, "If I was a Jew in
Russia..." Perhaps he felt the
question was a slur. "Are you
trying to say that I'm Jewish?
Watch your tongue, young
man!" he may have wanted to
reply.
Jews
In addition, Matveyev relied
on the some-of-my-best-friends-are-Jewish routine, citing a
friend of his named Polansky
who found no anti-Semitism in
Russia. He said, too, that
America had some "extreme
examples" of anti-Semitism. He
deleted from his speech, but
made available to the
News-Letter, references to
Jewish "clannishness" and
"curly-haired people with big
noses who think they're so
smart."
Most surprising was the fact
that he was there at all,
considering that he had been

newspaper reporter since the late
1940's in a country where a
misquoted official just doesn't
write an angry letter to the
editor. The machinations at the
New York Times are nothing
compared to the re-shufflings at
the Kremlin— and Izvestia. If
you can survive 38 purges, you
are truly a two-fisted,
thick-skinned, hard-nosed
journalist. The other problem
facing a Russian jo6rnalist is the
boredom comparable to a
university P.R. man, since
there's nothing to do but
re-write government statements.
There are no "hot stories," and,
besides, there's no one to scoop.
KOSYGIN NABBED IN LOVE
NEST; CP BIGWIG TAKES
BRIBE; and INSIDE A
SIBERIAN PRISON CAMP are
among the great stories you
never get to do. Matveyev, it
should be noted, spends most of
his time writing about and
visiting the United States, where
he can at last take out a
reporter's natural urge to do a
hatchet job on somebody.

J.R. Oppenheimer-science vs humanity at the Barn
By RICHARD ROSENTHAL
History was reenacted as
drama in the Theatre Hopkins
production ofIn the Matter ofJ.
Robert Oppenheimer, which
opened this weekend at the
Barn. Heinar Kipphardt's play,
translated from the German,
factually recreates the Atomic
Energy Commission's 1954
hearing to review the security
clearance of the noted nuclear
physicist.
The players in this excellent
Production portray with vivid
realism the tensions,
personalities and issues that
comprised the case. Dr.
Oppenheimer was suspected of
disloyalty to protect his friend
Chevalier, a professor of French
literature and confirmed
Communist, when the latter had
informed him of the possibility
of scientific espionage by the
Russians in 1942.

Second, Oppenheimer was
accused of impeding the progress
of the hydrogen bomb by
refusing to be enthusiastic about
the project.
W.P. Ellis, Humanities
professor at Essex Community
College, portrays the enigmatic
scientist with great insight and
sensitivity. The man whom
journalists named "father of the
atomic bomb," expresses his
painful moral scruples about
nuclear energy as applied to
warfare.
As an expert in service to the
government he was required to
determine how a bomb could be
dropped with maximum effect,
but this duty led him to the
inevitable schizophrenia of
today's scientist.
In one of the most moving
parts of the play, Oppenheimer
recollects his thoughts as he
witnessed the explosion of the

first hydrogen bomb at
Eniwetok Atoll in 1952. Two
passages from the Bhagavad
Cita stood out in his mind: "The
radiance of one thousand suns
which suddenly illuminate the
heavens, all in one moment—
thus the splendor of the
Lord."..."And I am Death, who
taketh all, who shatters worlds."
This he thought as the island of
Elugelab was obliterated.
Treason
Mr. Robb, counsel for the

A.E.C., is played by Robert
Walsh in one of the outstanding
performances of the evening.
Rob argues that Oppenheimer's
crime is "ideological treason."
His principal witness is Dr.
Edward Teller, the brilliant and
temperamental father of the
H-bomb. Teller 'testifies that he
first contemplated a
thermonuclear explosion with
Oppenheimer in 1942, but
criticizes Oppenheimer's
objection in 1945 to H-bomb

hydrogen bomb while other
people were playing around with

concludes that the tragedy of J.
Robert Oppenheimer was his
clinging to the utopian desire of
a classless society in a world

Jethro Tull
By MICHAEL HILL
"I was just driving down Baltimore
Street and I saw the big crowd around the
Civic Center, and Ifigured the Milwaukee
Bucks were in town. So I went in and
asked for a $5.50 seat. But when I got
inside it was all dark, and the basketball
court was nowhere around. And I looked
up on stage and wooee, it looked like
Dancing Harry had gotten together with a
bunch of his friends. This wierd lookin'
fellow was doing things that the Pearl
couldn't have done."
Ian Anderson's stage presence comes
over as something of a cross between Rudolph Nureyev and Joe Cocker. Swirling
hands and pointed, booted feet; flashing
eyes that must have been visible to the
back row of the Upper Concourse; an arched back and wild, flying hair, somehow
keeping time as the flute would swirl up
into another riff.
Jethro Tull was here Sunday night and
it was a battle of the egos the likes of
which hadn't been seen since Cream graced the Civic Center. Of course Ian Anderson, the best one-on-one singer in the
business, won, as per the game plan; but
it was quite a struggle and over 13,000
people really enjoyed watching.
The only problem was that the show
took place in the Civic Center. The Philadelphia 76ers had battled the Bullets
there the night before and the cavernous
hall was much more up for housing their
talents than it was for containing the
sounds of Tull.
Echoes abounded. Beats were impossible to distinguish as a rap from the snare
drum would come back at you a half second later. Anderson's incredible voice
would start out sounding like its amazing
self, and then quickly become muddled
and lost in the rebounding sounds.

Somehow it's not only the acoustics of
the Civic Center that are bothersome. The
massive entrances and exits, with their
square cinder block sides, seem more reasonable when filled with beer-swilling
hockey fans. Gaudily clad freaks somehow seem absurd disappearing into the
mass-production toilets. Hanging directly
above the stage during the evening were
the pennants won by the Bullets and Clippers, not to mention the neon U. S. flag,
which luckily never made an appearance.

But despite all that, Jethro Tull could
somehow make you forget. The bass player strutted back and forth in his zebra
suit and introduced one song with something about spending 18 months in an
asylum for exposing himself. All five preceded another song by standing in a line
and grunting out "New Day Yesterday."
Included in that line was the drummer
who wore a red hotpants outfit, complete
with knee socks and combat boots. Then
there was the keyboard man who stalked
acioss stage between the piano and organ,
his baggy white suit flowing with him,
looking something like Peter Ustinov after about six hits of sunshine.

boots and flowing coat at last at rest. He
had started it by singing the first lines of
"My God" followed by an incredible
flute solo that brought the house down.
He closed it, following the noise and intensity, quietly, singing the last lines to
"Wind Up,"("A song written to say `Tata'"), then striding suddenly offstage, and
again the applause was thunderous.
Ian Anderson had won, as everyone
had known he would. But somehow the
battle was still real and we had all enjoyed watching.

The fames Gang, a
rock trio, will be
featured at the
Civic Center on
Nov. 21, along
with Lighthouse,
and Mitch Ryder &
the Detroit Wheels.

Squash Club Strives
For Defense of Title
Well into this season's
competition in the Maryland
State Inter-Club Squash League,
the Homewood Squash Club
boasts a 3-0 record, placing them
in a two-way tie for first place
with the Baltimore Racquet
Club.
Homewood thus far has
decisively defeated the Maryland
Club, 4-1, and the Towson "Y,"
4-1, indicating the traditional
superiority of Homewood's
squash players. The Homewood
team is the defending Maryland
State League team champion
and is clearly the favorite to win
the title again this year.
The only threat to
Homewood appears to be posed
by the Racquet Club, with
whom the Blue Jays have yet to
;lash this season.
For the past three years, the
domewood Squash Club has
been directed by its co-founders
Gaither Davis and John Hament,
who are also the numbers one
and two players respectively.
Both have had formal training in
New England prep schools:

Davis at Saint Paul's in New
Hampshire, and Hament at
Phillip's Academy, Andover
Massachusetts.
Resigning
However, as of Friday,
Hament announced that, in
favor of tennis, he is resigning
from the team and turning over
his captain's duties to Steven
Anderson, who moves up the
ladder now to the number three
position.
Anderson, who learned in
Southern California, has also
played for the team since its
conception.
Newcomers this year are John
Russel-Wood, a professor in the
History Department, who has
played only England until this
year, and David Garrison, a
superb touch player, who is a
graduate student in the
Department of Romance
Languages. Bob Hogan, a
professor in the Psychology
Department, and Bob Shaffer of
the Physics Department will be
competing for the now vacant
fifth position.

SPORTS BRIEFS
BLUE JAY ESPATOON TEAM
The undefeated Blue Jay
espatoon squad clinched its
fourth straight IRT Conference
title on Tuesday by edging
Klopfenstein, 32 trubbles to 34.
Harvey Hommitz again led the
way with 27 trubbles and a
record 147 lugs. On Sunday the
team takes on Excelsior at
Okeechobee. Coach Alex
Brumblebush is hopeful that a
win over the Warthogs will earn
the Jays a berth in the NCAA
post-season tourney.

N-L BASKETBALL TEAM
Since last report, the N-L
team has considerably improved
its prospects for a winning
season by acquiring certain key
players from the ranks of
professional basketball.
First of all, Bruce Bortz and
two typewriters were recently
traded for ABA reject, Wayne
Hightower, a 6'10" stilt who
should help rookie Bill Witting

considerably in the center
position.
Coach Bones McKinney said
that he traded Bortz because he
didn't want to see Bruce
benched all season while a
typewriter played the other
forward position.
Other moves made by the N-L
"Magicians of Basketball"
included the trading of Steve
Tulloss "Honey Comb," for

Lattin. Coach Jack McMahon
said that he was glad about the
trade because he had "been
trying to get rid of that bum

rookie, Ed "Hondo" Brethauer,
was traded for vereral
