Lemon" and midget guard, Red
"Curly" Klautz (origator of the
two handed set shot).

Hopkins Swordsmen
Seeking League Title
By INGRAM ROBERTS
This winter the Hopkins
fencers renew their pursuit of
the Middle Atlantic Conference
championship, which for the
past two years they have
narrowly missed capturing from
defending champion Temple.
The team will also enter the
North Atlantic Championships
and the NCAA championships
this year.
The Blue Jays will be
bolstered by five returning
lettermen: Co-Captains Keith
Bucklen and Ingram Roberts,
Jeff Rosenbaum, Tas Coroneos,
and Gary Green. Last year
Rosenbaum, Bucklen, and
Roberts were named to All-MAC
team. For the first time in recent
years, five out of nine starters
will be lettermen. The squad
should be strong and have a

good chance at improving on last
year's 6-5 record.
Besides the usual matches
against MAC opponents
Haverford, Drew, Stevens,
Lafayette, Muhlenberg, and
Temple, the team will be taking
a trip to New England and New
York City during mini-mester.
The fencers will take on 8 teams
including Harvard and MIT
during the course of this tour.
Other Opponents
Other matches against
perennial foes Duke, Virginia,
and Penn State are also on tap.
The team members are
optimistically viewing this year's
season, and feel it will be
perhaps both the most exciting
and successful one since 1967,
when Hopkins won the North
Atlantic Conference
Championship.

NEWS-LETTER

Woman Claims Abortion Clinic 'Nightmare'
By HOWARD WEAVER
The Wickersham Women's
Medical Clinic, an abortion clinic
which advertises in the
' News-Letter, has come under
attack from a Canadian woman
who was referred to the center
by her doctor.
The Toronto Globe and Mail,
in a November 5 story, told of
the woman's stay at the clinic,
which she described as a
"nightmare experience." She
went to the clinic in September,

after she failed in her attempt to
have the abortion in Toronto.
The Wickersham Clinic is in New
York.
The young woman — in her
early twenties — is the mother of
two children. She sought the
abortion because she is separated
from her husband and felt that
she could not afford another
child. An office worker, she
earns about $115 per week; she
borrowed the $400 needed for
the abortion, and spent another

$200 for travel costs.
The woman reported
inefficiency and neglect at the
clinic, which charged her $400
to abort the 18-week pregnancy.
The clinic, which in its
advertising bills the service as a
"Model Abortion Program," was
crowded and poorly staffed, she
said. Members of the clinic staff
treated her in a "contemptuous
and humiliating manner" during
her stay, according to the
woman.

Abortion Ads Challenged
By GARY SOULSMAN
The Diamondback, the
University of Maryland's student
newspaper, has come under
attack by the Knights of
Columbus for running abortion
referral ads.
The News-Letter runs similar
ads and is among numerous
organizations which the Knights
claim are violating Maryland's
1968 abortion law.
The Diamondback has
rejected a request from the
Knights to drop their
advertisements and it has
challenged the Knights to file
suit. The Catholic Men's
organization is presently
awaiting the opinion of
Maryland's Attorney General,
Francis Burch, to determine
whether or not they have a valid
case.
Joseph Mauro who is leading
the campaign for the Knights
said in an interview with the

Sunpapers, "We are dealing with
human life and this far
outweighs a newspaper's right to
publish these advertisements."
The controversy over
abortions stems from
an
by
interpretation
anti-abortionist groups such as
the Knights, over Maryland's
abortion law, which states that
abortions may be performed by
licensed physicians in
state-licensed hospitals.
One particular aspect of the
bill forbids "giving advice or
counsel information" or
assistance "by any means
whatever...for termination of
human pregnancy by such
physician in such hospital."
The Knights have interpreted
this to mean that any agency is
violating the law if it participates
in the practice of referring
Maryland women to Washington
where the red tape is less and the
abortions are cheaper.

Baltimore's branch of Planned
Parenthood which has been
referring people to Washington
has decided to ignore the
controversy. According to Carl
Speckman, the branch's director,
his organization has no choice
but to continue its referrals as
long as inadequate facilities are
called on to handle a greater
number of women seeking
abortions than they can handle.
Ironically, the Maryland State
Department of Health and
Mental Hygiene maternity and
family planning section has been
investigating the possibility of
establishing a permanent
relationship with a Washington
clinic to handle Maryland cases.
The agency thinks this would be
preferred by most women since
on the average abortions are
$150 cheaper there. However,
this organization will not send
anyone to Washington until the
present controversy is resolved.

The woman's alleged ordeal
began at 1:00 p.m., when she
and a number of other women
were told to report to the clinic.
After completing a form of
personal questions, she signed a
statement authorizing the
procedure, and the use of any
anesthetic required. The forms
listed her doctor as I. Saxe, but
she says that he was not
available for the actual abortion;
she does not know the name of
the young doctor who actually
carried out the saline-injection
procedure.
After a brief examination, she
was taken to a four-bed room
and the injection and a local

anesthetic were administered.
About 9:00 p.m., she began
labor, and started delivery at
4:00 a.m., but the nurse refused
to change the bed-linen until the
delivery was complete. No one
came to advise or help her
during the delivery, she said. She
was finally taken from the wet
bed at 10:00 a.m. Sunday, six
hours later. She was awakened at
6:00 a.m. Monday morning, and
kept waiting for examination
until 9:00 a.m.
"There's no privacy," she
said. "Half the time they don't
even close the door and there are
male staff walking about. The
cleaners walk in and out."
